column1: Barking is a district of East London and the administrative centre of the London Borough of Barking and Dagenham
column2: with a population of 59
column3: 068. It is 9.3 miles (15 km) east northeast of Charing Cross. It was historically an ancient parish in the county of Essex that straddled the River Roding. It underwent a shift from fishing and farming to market gardening and industrial development on the River Thames. Barking railway station opened in 1854 and has been served by the London Underground since 1908. As part of the suburban growth of London in the 20th century
column4: Barking significantly expanded and increased in population
column5: primarily due to the development of the London County Council estate at Becontree in the 1920s
column6: and became a municipal borough in 1931
column7: and part of Greater London in 1965. In addition to an extensive and fairly low-density residential area
column8: the town centre forms a large retail and commercial district
column9: currently a focus for regeneration. The former industrial lands to the south are being redeveloped as Barking Riverside.

column1: == Origins and Administration ==
=== Toponymy ===
Its name came from Anglo-Saxon Berecingas
column2: meaning either "the settlement of the followers or descendants of a man called Bereca" or "the settlement by the birch trees". In AD 735 the area was Berecingum and was known to mean "dwellers among the birch trees". By AD 1086
column3: it had become Berchingae as evidenced by the manor's entry in the Domesday Book.

column1: === Manor of Barking ===
Barking was a huge Manor (landholding)
column2: first mentioned in a charter in 735 AD (though the Abbey is believed to have been founded in 666 AD). The Manor covered the areas now known as Barking
column3: Dagenham and Ilford. The Manor was held by the Nunnery of Barking.

column1: === Parishes ===
By the late 1100s (the Parishes of England were
column2: with a few exceptions
column3: fixed for around 700 years from the late 12th century onwards) the huge Manor of Barking was served by two Ancient Parishes
column4: Barking and Dagenham. This reversed the usual situation (for smaller
column5: and even quite large Manors) where a parish would serve one or more manors. As with other manors
column6: the area held by the declined over time
column7: but the parish boundaries based on its former extent remained constant.

column1: The Parish of Barking covered the areas now known as Barking and Ilford. Barking was a large ancient parish of 12
column2: 307 acres (49.80 km2) in the Becontree hundred of Essex. It was divided into the wards of Chadwell
column3: Ilford
column4: Ripple and Town. A local board was formed for Town ward in 1882 and it was extended to cover Ripple ward in 1885. In 1888 Ilford and Chadwell were split off as a new parish of Ilford

column1: === Modern local government ===

The parish became Barking Town Urban District in 1894 and the local board became an urban district council. The urban district was incorporated as the Municipal Borough of Barking in 1931. It was abolished in 1965 and split
column2: with the majority merged with the former area of the Municipal Borough of Dagenham to form the London Borough of Barking. The part west of the River Roding
column3: which included part of Beckton
column4: became part of the London Borough of Newham. In 1980 the borough was renamed Barking and Dagenham.

column1: == History ==
=== Abbey ===
The manor of Barking was the site of Barking Abbey
column2: a nunnery founded in 666 by Eorcenwald
column3: Bishop of London
column4: destroyed by the Danes and reconstructed in 970 by King Edgar. The celebrated writer Marie de France may have been abbess of the nunnery in the late 12th century. At the Dissolution of the Monasteries in 1536
column5: Barking Abbey was demolished; the parish church of St Margaret
column6: some walling and foundations are all that remain. The parish church is an example of Norman architecture; Captain James Cook married Elizabeth Batts of Shadwell there in 1762
column7: and it is the burial place of many members of the Fanshawe family of Parsloes Manor.

column1: === Market ===
A charter issued between 1175 and 1179 confirms the ancient market right. The market declined in the 18th century but has since been revived.
=== Architecture: historic buildings ===
St Margaret's Church is a grade I listed building in the Abbey Green area of the Town Centre
column2: dating back to the 13th century. It is built within the grounds of Barking Abbey
column3: a former royal monastery
column4: whose ruins are recognisable for its partially restored Grade-II* Listed Curfew Tower
column5: which features on the coat of arms of the London Borough of Barking and Dagenham.

column1: Eastbury Manor House in Barking is a Grade I listed 16th century Elizabethan manor house and museum run by the National Trust.
=== Fishing ===
Fishing was the most important industry from the 14th until the mid-19th centuries. Salt water fishing began before 1320
column2: when too fine nets were seized by City authorities
column3: but expanded greatly from the 16th century. Fisher Street (now the southern part of Abbey Road) was named after the fishing community there. From about 1775 welled and dry smacks were used
column5: and rigged as gaff cutters. Fishermen sailed as far as Iceland in the summer. They served Billingsgate Fish Market in the City of London
column6: and moored in Barking Pool. Scymgeour Hewett
column8: founded the Short Blue Fleet (England's biggest fishing fleet) based in Barking
column9: using smacks out of Barking and east coast ports. Around 1870 this fleet changed to gaff ketches that stayed out at sea for months; to preserve the fish they used ice produced by flooding local fields in winter. Fleeting involved fish being ferried from fishing smacks to gaff cutters by little wooden ferry-boats. The rowers had to stand
column10: as the boats were piled high with fish boxes. Rowers refused to wear their bulky cork lifejackets because it slowed down their rowing. At first the fast 50-foot gaff cutters with great booms projecting beyond the sterns raced the fish to port to get the best prices.Until about 1870 the trade was mostly in live fish
column11: using welled smacks in which the central section of the hull
column13: was pierced to create a 'well' in which seawater could circulate. Cod caught live were lowered into this well
column15: and remained alive until the vessel returned to port
column16: when they were transferred to semi-submerged 'chests'
column18: which kept them alive until they were ready for sale. At this point they were pulled out and killed with a blow on the head before being despatched to market
column19: where because of their freshness they commanded a high price. People who practised this method of fishing were known as 'codbangers'.By 1850 there some 220 smacks
column21: 370 men and boys. The boats were typically 75 feet (23 m) long carrying up to 50 tons. During the wars of the 17th and 18th centuries they were often used as fleet auxiliaries by the Royal Navy
column22: based at nearby Chatham Dockyard. The opening of rail links between the North Sea ports and London meant it was quicker to transport fish by train straight to the capital rather than waiting for ships to take the longer route down the east coast and up the River Thames. By the 1850s the Thames was so severely polluted that fish kept in chests quickly died. Consequently
column23: the fishery slipped into decline in the second half of the 19th century. The decline was hastened by a storm in December 1863
column25: which caused the deaths of 60 men and damage estimated at £6000–7000. Many of its leading figures
column27: moved to Great Yarmouth and Grimsby. By 1900 Barking had ceased to be a fishing port
column28: leaving only street and pub names as a reminder. A large modern steel sculpture entitled "The Catch" is another reminder. The sculpture is on the roundabout at the end of Fanshawe Avenue. The local fishing heritage is recorded at Valence House Museum.

column1: === Economic development ===
Boat building has a long history
column2: being used for the repair of some royal ships of Henry VIII. In 1848
column3: 5 shipwrights
column7: and block-makers are listed in a local trade directory. Hewett & Co continued in boat building and repair until 1899. Other industries replaced the nautical trades
column9: paint and chemicals manufacture. By 1878 Daniel de Pass had opened the Barking Guano Works (later de Pass Fertilisers Ltd
column10: part of Fisons) at Creekmouth. Creekmouth was also the site of the major Barking Power Station from 1925 until the 1970s
column11: burning coal shipped in by river; the current station known as Barking is further east near Dagenham Dock. In the 20th century new industrial estates were established
column12: and many local residents came to be employed in the car plant at Dagenham.

column1: === Thames disaster ===
On 3 September 1878 the iron ship Bywell Castle ran into the pleasure steamer Princess Alice in Gallions Reach
column2: downstream of Barking Creek. The paddle steamer was returning from the coast via Sheerness and Gravesend with nearly 800-day trippers. She broke in two and sank immediately
column3: with the loss of more than 600 lives
column4: the highest single loss of civilian lives in UK territorial waters. At that time there was no official body responsible for marine safety in the Thames; but the official enquiry resolved that the Marine Police Force based at Wapping be equipped with steam launches to replace their rowing boats to help them perform rescues.

column1: == Economy ==
Vicarage Field Shopping Centre is located on Ripple Road in Barking town centre. It was opened in November 1990.
== Geography ==
=== Town centre ===

Barking Town Centre is being regenerated through a number of schemes. It is one of the most deprived areas of Barking. The Abbey and Gascoigne wards in the town centre are ranked 823rd and 554th respectively - within the 10% most deprived wards in the country.The regeneration aims to achieve a more sustainable economy by investing in new quality retail outlets and creating a business centre; and to widen employment prospects
column2: mainly by creating new "retail and business accommodation"
column3: to increase the income of both existing and new residents. The regeneration also aims to improve people's skills. This is mainly achieved through the Barking Learning Centre
column5: numeracy and other basic skills people may be lacking due to a previous lack of educational development. It currently acts as a borough-based learning facility. It was officially opened on 10 June 2008 by John Denham
column7: Universities and Skills.The town centre development intends to improve the quality and range of housing
column9: 000 new homes: 25% will be intermediate housing
column10: affordable for local residents to buy. There will be 4
column12: making it easier for first-time buyers and people with low incomes to rent a property. To help make the development more sustainable
column13: all private sector homes were to meet the Government's decency standards by 2010.Plans for the new town square were unveiled in September 2007. The development is part of the Mayor of London's 100 Public Spaces
column15: designed by muf architecture/art and Allford Hall Monaghan and Morris. It won the European Prize for Urban Public Space.

column1: === Roding Riverside ===
Not to be confused with Barking Riverside
column2: Roding Riverside is a name given to an area of Barking comprising the stretch of Abbey Road south of St Pauls Road
column3: which runs parallel to the River Roding / Barking Creek and the area between. The quarter is post-industrial. Many buildings are late 20th century or early 21st century residential and commercial buildings
column4: but some are Victorian industrial buildings adapted for use in arts and leisure fields
column5: including a contemporary art gallery (the Laura I Gallery)
column6: with a view to regenerating the area in part by drawing out the industrial heritage architecture.

column1: One such Victorian building is a former Malthouse. Adjacent to this building stands a cluster of buildings together styled the Ice House Quarter
column2: which includes a former Ice House and a former Boat HouseA new building
column3: Ice House Court references the old Ice House and provides more artist studio space.

column1: === Barking Riverside ===
The Barking Riverside development is part of the London Riverside project
column2: which aims to regenerate the Thames riverside area of East London through new homes
column3: jobs
column4: and services. Barking Riverside consists of 350 acres (1.4 km2) of brownfield land and therefore needs site clearance and the removal of overhead power lines before it can go ahead. Construction began in 2008
column8: 000 people. New transport links will be provided
column9: including East London Transit and the extension of the Docklands Light Railway at Barking Riverside DLR station
column10: and City Hall is seeking £150 million to extend the Gospel Oak to Barking Line of the London Overground from Barking railway station to Barking Riverside.

column1: Barking and Dagenham Council has said that it does not believe the 10
column2: 800-home brownfield development to be viable without improved transport connections
column3: and expects that the Treasury is likely to confirm funding in the Chancellor of the Exchequer's Autumn 2013 statement. The development will also provide new public facilities
column6: leisure and cultural amenities". Two new primary schools and one secondary school will be built
column7: and the public will have access to two kilometres of Thames river front. The Rivergate Centre
column8: designed by van Heyningen and Haward Architects
column9: provides the civic facilities for the initial phase of Barking Riverside
column10: while a new square and 3FE primary school
column14: flexible office suites for the PCT and Community Development Trust
column15: as well as a MUGA and sports pitches are also planned. As yet unbuilt
column17: local shops and a neighbourhood police post.

column1: == Demography ==
Barking is highly ethnically diverse. In the 2011 census
column2: the largest ethnic group in Abbey ward (which covers Barking town centre) was Pakistani at 17%
column3: followed by 16% White British
column5: 13% Indian and 11% Other White. Gascoigne ward (southern Barking) was 26% White British
column6: 26% Black African and 13% Other White. Longbridge ward (eastern Barking) was 35% White British
column7: 18% Bangladeshi and 11% Pakistani. The wards of Dagenham meanwhile are all White British-majority
column8: with Black Africans the second largest racial demographic there
column9: whereas the Asian community is small by contrast to Barking.Barkings population grew steadily after urbanisation began in the late 19th century.

column1: Barking's population (if defined as approximating to the Abbey
column2: Eastbury
column3: Gascoigne and Longbridge wards) was 48

column1: == Education ==
Primary schools include Northbury Primary School
column2: Eastbury Primary School
column3: St Margaret's Church of England and St Joseph's Roman Catholic.

column1: Secondary schools include Barking Abbey School. Lady Aisha Academy is an independent Muslim Girls Secondary School which opened in September 2011 on Victoria Road.
== Transport ==

The town is situated north of the A13 road and east of the River Roding near its confluence with the River Thames in east London. The South Woodford to Barking Relief Road (part of the A406 North Circular Road) runs through the Roding Valley
column2: and access to the town centre is by its junction with the A124
column3: which until the late 1920s was the main route to and from London. Barking station is a local transport hub and is served by the London Underground
column5: c2c and London Bus and East London Transit routes. The east of Barking is served by Upney Underground station. The East London Transit bus rapid transit has a station beside the Vicarage Field Shopping Centre. The western end of the Yiwu-London railway line from China to the UK is located in Barking at the DB Eurohub. It ran its first service in January 2017.

column1: == Culture ==
=== Music ===
The singer-songwriter and activist Billy Bragg was born in Barking.Neil Young recorded two tracks for his classic album Harvest
column2: "A Man Needs a Maid" and "There's a World" with the London Symphony Orchestra at Barking Assembly Hall (now the Broadway theatre)
column3: released in 1972.

column1: Electronic band Underworld named their 2010 album Barking after the town. The band are associated with nearby Romford.
Irish band U2's guitarist Dave Evans (known as the Edge) was born in Barking to Welsh parents.
The artist Ramz wrote a song called "Barking" in 2017.
English singer Megan McKenna was born in Barking.
=== Local media ===

Bedrock is the local hospital radio service available online to the local area and broadcasting a range of health-related information focused on the local King George Hospital in Goodmayes and Queen's Hospital in Romford.
=== Sport ===
Barking F.C. are a non-league side. The team merged with East Ham F.C. to form Barking & East Ham United in 2001. This club later struggled and went out of business
column2: but Barking F.C. was later reformed once again. Cricket
column3: basketball and hockey are also popular sports in the area.

column1: Notable footballers from Barking include former England captains and defenders Bobby Moore and John Terry. The successful racing driver Scott Malvern who has won British and European Championships in Formula Ford and Formula Renault was born in Barking Hospital. Jason Leonard
column2: who won 119 caps as a rugby union prop forward
column3: was born in Barking and began his club career at Barking RFC.

column1: A free to enter 5 km (3.1 miles) Parkrun takes place every Saturday morning at Barking Park
column2: at 9am
column3: as well as most Boxing Days. The course has two laps and is quite flat. It starts north of the tennis courts and follows most of the boating lake
column4: doubles back along the tree-lined avenue
column5: past the tennis courts again and up to the path running parallel to Longbridge Road.

column1: === Public art works ===
Barking Town Centre has a number of recently commissioned sculptures and public art works.

column2: two small stones from remains of the medieval London Bridge were joined together in a sculpture in front of St Margaret's church facing the Barking Abbey ruins as part of several public artworks placed in Barking Town Centre by artist Joost Van Santen.
